aXtO.text: I have the simplest tastes. I am always satisfied with the best.
aXtO.author: Oscar Wilde

pRia.text: Cautious, careful people, always casting about to preserve their reputation and social standing, never can bring about a reform. Those who are really in earnest must be willing to be anything or nothing in the world's estimation.
pRia.author: Susan B. Anthony

qoEp.text: It isn't enough to talk about peace. One must believe in it. And it isn't enough to believe in it. One must work at it.
qoEp.author: Eleanor Roosevelt

gleH.text: It takes courage to love, but pain through love is the purifying fire which those who love generously know.
gleH.author: Eleanor Roosevelt

choA.text: Will people ever be wise enough to refuse to follow bad leaders or to take away the freedom of other people?
choA.author: Eleanor Roosevelt

goaC.text: One should always sleep in all of one's guest beds, to make sure that they are comfortable.
goaC.author: Eleanor Roosevelt

Prle.text: The hour of departure has arrived, and we go our ways — I to die and you to live. Which is the better, only God knows.
Prle.author: Socrates

yiuY.text: A man who is good for anything ought not to calculate the chance of living or dying; he ought only to consider whether in doing anything he is doing right or wrong — acting the part of a good man or a bad.
yiuY.author: Socrates

cRia.text: Just as it is better to illuminate than merely to shine, so to pass on what one has contemplated is better than merely to contemplate.
cRia.author: Thomas Aquinas

rouR.text: It is only when we think abstractly that we have such a high opinion of man. Of men in the concrete, most of us think the vast majority very bad.
rouR.author: Bertrand Russell

stOe.text: The most essential characteristic of scientific technique is that it proceeds from experiment, not from tradition.
stOe.author: Bertrand Russell

qnyZ.text: There are two motives for reading a book: one, that you enjoy it; the other, that you can boast about it.
qnyZ.author: Bertrand Russell

koEd.text: The Laws ought to be so framed, that no one Citizen should stand in Fear of another; but that all of them should stand in Fear of the same Laws.
koEd.author: Catherine II of Russia

soUc.text: If you want to read a perfect book there is only one way: write it.
soUc.author: Ambrose Bierce

Xoam.text: While you have a future do not live too much in contemplation of your past: unless you are content to walk backward the mirror is a poor guide.
Xoam.author: Ambrose Bierce

moAs.text: A crust eaten in peace is better than a banquet partaken in anxiety.
moAs.author: Aesop

Trle.text: Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
Trle.author: Aesop

plEd.text: An idea starts to be interesting when you get scared of taking it to its logical conclusion.
plEd.author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb

tRoe.text: It does not matter how frequently something succeeds if failure is too costly to bear.
tRoe.author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb

boUb.text: Men do not differ much about what things they will call evils; they differ enormously about what evils they will call excusable.
boUb.author: G. K. Chesterton

gieY.text: How many valiant men we have seen to survive their own reputation!
gieY.author: Michel de Montaigne

xLaz.text: Democracy is the theory that the common people know what they want, and deserve to get it good and hard.
xLaz.author: H. L. Mencken

sieW.text: We are here and it is now: further than that, all human knowledge is moonshine.
sieW.author: H. L. Mencken

nieC.text: I have never killed any one, but I have read some obituary notices with great satisfaction.
nieC.author: Clarence Darrow

spIa.text: It is dangerous to be right in matters where established men are wrong.
spIa.author: Voltaire

Riuj.text: I have been complimented many times and they always embarrass me; I always feel that they have not said enough.
Riuj.author: Mark Twain

jlEm.text: I was born lazy. I am no lazier now than I was forty years ago, but that is because I reached the limit forty years ago. You can't go beyond possibility.
jlEm.author: Mark Twain

swLe.text: We live in the midst of alarms; anxiety beclouds the future; we expect some new disaster with each newspaper we read.
swLe.author: Abraham Lincoln

foAs.text: As I would not be a slave, so I would not be a master. This expresses my idea of democracy. Whatever differs from this, to the extent of the difference, is no democracy.
foAs.author: Abraham Lincoln

sIup.text: In real life, the hardest aspect of the battle between good and evil is determining which is which.
sIup.author: George R. R. Martin

Bria.text: The most improper job of any man [...] is bossing other men. Not one in a million is fit for it, and least of all those who seek the opportunity.
Bria.author: J. R. R. Tolkien

drlU.text: Nothing in life is so exhilarating as to be shot at without result.
drlU.author: Winston Churchill

Nnoi.text: Victory attained by violence is tantamount to a defeat, for it is momentary.
Nnoi.author: Mahatma Gandhi

MRsy.text: An error does not become truth by reason of multiplied propagation, nor does truth become error because nobody sees it. Truth stands, even if there be no public support. It is self sustained.
MRsy.author: Mahatma Gandhi

mLLq.text: It is unwise to be too sure of one's own wisdom. It is healthy to be reminded that the strongest might weaken and the wisest might err.
mLLq.author: Mahatma Gandhi

zojg.text: Victorious warriors win first and then go to war, while defeated warriors go to war first and then seek to win.
zojg.author: Sun Tzu

uvgC.text: The best way to solve any problem is to remove the cause.
uvgC.author: Martin Luther King, Jr.

PDzA.text: Nonviolence is a powerful and just weapon. Indeed, it is a weapon unique in history, which cuts without wounding and ennobles the man who wields it.
PDzA.author: Martin Luther King, Jr.

wHWU.text: You can't use up creativity. The more you use, the more you have.
wHWU.author: Maya Angelou

WtqH.text: Success is like reaching an important birthday and finding you're exactly the same.
WtqH.author: Audrey Hepburn

dCWv.text: My friends are my "estate." Forgive me then the avarice to hoard them.
dCWv.author: Emily Dickinson

CyoF.text: When one door of happiness closes, another opens; but often we look so long at the closed door that we do not see the one which has been opened for us.
CyoF.author: Helen Keller

CGsW.text: One can never consent to creep when one feels an impulse to soar.
CGsW.author: Helen Keller

lqew.text: We differ, blind and seeing, one from another, not in our senses, but in the use we make of them, in the imagination and courage with which we seek wisdom beyond the senses.
lqew.author: Helen Keller

mvJN.text: Perhaps when we find ourselves wanting everything, it is because we are dangerously near to wanting nothing.
mvJN.author: Sylvia Plath

ktEI.text: Painting's not important. The important thing is keeping busy.
ktEI.author: Grandma Moses

Ksdc.text: A primitive artist is an amateur whose work sells.
Ksdc.author: Grandma Moses

uziz.text: Life is not a series of gig lamps symmetrically arranged; life is a luminous halo, a semi-transparent envelope surrounding us from the beginning of consciousness to the end.
uziz.author: Virginia Woolf

hLpW.text: The nice thing about having a brain is that one can learn, that ignorance can be supplanted by knowledge, and that small bits of knowledge can gradually pile up into substantial heaps.
hLpW.author: Douglas Hofstadter

Rbft.text: We don't have to save the world. The world is big enough to look after itself. What we have to be concerned about is whether or not the world we live in will be capable of sustaining us in it.
Rbft.author: Douglas Adams

lKev.text: It can hardly be a coincidence that no language on Earth has ever produced the expression "As pretty as an airport."
lKev.author: Douglas Adams

bvvG.text: Be slow in choosing a Friend, slower in changing.
bvvG.author: Benjamin Franklin
